section.title: Form: An HTML Form Fields Generation Utility

refnamediv.refpurpose: The form packages creates a form object that can be manipulated to generate HTML forms

refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: The form package is a utility to generating html forms. A form object command saves the programmer from typing the cumbersome html code of input elements, working out a solution for better standardization and readability of the code. form requires that just the basic information of interest to the code are typed, greatly simplyfing the development of forms. Option to the command are treated as a list of parameter-value pairs that become the defaults for the corresponding attributes of the form.

A form object has specialized menthods to generate all the standard input fields, i.e. text, password, hidden, generic button, submit or reset buttons and image. form creates select input fields, radiobutton and checkbox boolean options groups. Also new inputs introduced with HTML5 are supported: color, date, datetime, datetime-local, email, file, month, number, range, search, tel, time, url, week.
Other input elements can be generated using the general purpose 'field' method.

refsect1.title: Form Object Commands
refsect1.para: Form Objects are Tcl commands that need subcommands to invoke specific actions on an object. They have a general syntax that follow this scheme:

Where name is to become the value of a 'name' attribute in input field tag. The list of switches that follows name is copied into the a tag as attribute="value" pairs. Some subcommand (e.g. form, radiobuttons and checkboxes) treat specific options in a way that fits the specific organization and function of these fields.

listitem.para: generate the <form> tag with all of its arguments. This command must be called as first in the form generation process. The following is a sample of code creating a form named 'formname' whose data will be sent with menthod GET and initialized with data stored in array 'response'
listitem.programlisting: form myform -defaults response -method get -name formname myform start myform text text_entry -size 20 myform select option_selected -values {opt1 opt2 opt3 opt4} myform submit submit -value Search myform end
listitem.para: The code collects the input field values and send them through GET method to the same form URL for further processing. Use the -action switch to specify a different URL to process the data
The method to be used to encode the form data. Possible values are get or post
listitem.note: At the time of writing only the 'get' method is implemented

listitem.para: a name for the form being generated: this value becomes the value of the attribute 'name' in the <form> tag.

an array of default values to be assigned to the fields of the form. Every name in the array is matched with an input field, when a given field gets added to the form it is initialized with the value of the corresponding variable in the array. This option works well in conjuction with the load_response command of Rivet when default values come from another form.
The URL to the procedure data are being sent to. If no -action switch is specified the data are sent to the form's URL.
generate the </form> closing tag. This command must be called as last in the form generation process
emit a field of the given type and name, including any default key-value pairs defined for this field type and optional key-value pairs included with the statement

the radiobutton creates a whole radiobutton group with the values and labels specified in the argument list. If no -labels switch is passed to the subcommand the values are printed as labels of the radiobutton. Example:
listitem.programlisting: form myform -defaults response -method get -name formname myform start myform text text_entry -size 20 myform radiobuttons fruit -values {big medium small} \ -labels {Watermelon Orange Strawberry} \ -class myradiobclass myform submit submit -value Search myform end
listitem.para: will generate the following HTML code.
listitem.programlisting: <input type="radio" name="fruit" class="myradiobclass" value="big" />Watermelon <input type="radio" name="fruit" class="myradiobclass" value="medium" />Orange <input type="radio" name="fruit" class="myradiobclass" value="small" />Strawberry
listitem.para: if the 'response' array has a variable for the name 'fruit' the corresponding radiobutton field is automatically checked. The options values and labels are used internally and don't get into the tag attributes. If a labels switch is not given labels are generated using the values list.
The checkbox subcommand emits a checkbox type input field with the name, label and value attributes set accordingly to the parameters passed to the subcommand. Example, the following code:
listitem.programlisting: myform checkbox options -value opt1 -label "Option 1" myform checkbox options -value opt2 -label "Option 2" myform checkbox options -value opt3 -label "Option 3" myform checkbox options -value opt4 -label "Option 4"
listitem.para: Provided opt2 was in the list valued response array (in the 'options' variable) that initialized the form, the output would look like this
listitem.programlisting: <input type="checkbox" name="options" label="Option 1" value="opt1" />Option 1 <input type="checkbox" name="options" label="Option 2" value="opt2" checked="checked" />Option 2 <input type="checkbox" name="options" label="Option 3" value="opt3" />Option 3 <input type="checkbox" name="options" label="Option 4" value="opt4" />Option 4
